section.title: The Skeleton Page
section.para: An &oof2; &skel; is a bare-bones object containing geometric information about a &mesh;. It is composed of &elems;, &nodes;, and &sgmts;. It also includes boundaries (PointBoundary and EdgeBoundary) where &mesh; boundary conditions will be applied.

A &skel; is in essence a discretized geometric representation of µ. A &mesh; is created by adding muscles (material properties) and internal organs (mathematical properties) onto a &skel;. Thus, the validity of a &mesh; is critically dependent on how faithfully its &skel; has been adapted to the &material; (pixel) boundaries present in its µ.
This Skeleton Page contains tools that are used in creating, managing, and modifying &skels; so that they conform to material boundaries.

The layout of the Skeleton Page follows that of the Image and Pixel Selection pages. At the top of the page is a Skeleton Chooser, which selects the &skel; to which the operations on the page apply. Like the Image Chooser on the Image Page, the Skeleton Chooser is in two parts. The first part chooses a µ, and the second part chooses one of the &skels; within it.

simplesect.title: Buttons
simplesect.para:
Below the Skeleton Chooser is a row of buttons for performing common &skel; operations. The first three buttons create &skels;, and set the Skeleton Chooser to the newly created &skel;:
The New button creates a new &skel; with a given number of &elems;. The &skel; will be created in the µ specified by the first part of the Skeleton Chooser. The &skel; will have a uniform rectangular array of &elems;, and the &elems; will not have any relationship to the &material; boundaries in the µ. It will almost certainly be necessary to modify the &skel; for it to be a good representation of the µ.
The Simple button creates a new &skel; with one quadrilateral or two triangular &elems; for each pixel of in the µ. The &skel; will be created in the µ specified by the first part of the Skeleton Chooser. A &skel; created in this way already matches the &material; boundaries in the µ, so it doesn't need any modification. However, it probably creates far more elements than are necessary to represent the µ and also includes unphysical jagged edges.
The Auto button creates a new &skel; and automatically refines it to fit the µ, using a predefined set of operations. The operations may not be suitable for all µs;, but often do a very good job.
The remaining buttons act on the &skel; currently selected in the Skeleton Chooser:
The Rename button renames the current &skel; and leaves it selected in the Skeleton Chooser.
The Copy button makes a copy of the current &skel;. The copy becomes the new current &skel;.
The Delete button deletes the current &skel; and all &meshes; associated with it. It does not otherwise affect the &skel;'s µ.
The Save button saves the current &skel; in a file. (The Save button is exactly the same as the Save/Skeleton command in the File menu, except that the Save button operates on the &skel; named in the Skeleton Chooser, while the File command can save any &skel;.)

simplesect.title: The Skeleton Modification Pane
simplesect.para: The Skeleton Modification Pane contains tools for modifying a &skel; so that it follows the &material; and pixel group boundaries in its µ. See the discussions of the command and the subclasses to learn about the specific tools.

At the top of the pane (see ) is a chooser (marked method) for picking a modification method. The parameters of the method appear below it. Below that are five buttons:
The OK button applies the selected modifier to the current &skel; by invoking the command.
The Undo and Redo buttons undo and redo the latest &skel; modifications.
The Prev and Next buttons cycle the method chooser through the recently applied methods. They have no direct effect on the &skel;.
